intro: Quercus griffithii var. glanduligera, commonly known as the glandular chinquapin, is a deciduous tree native to the western United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its lobed leaves and acorns with a distinctive glandular structure. The plant has a rugged, twisted trunk and often grows in rocky or arid environments. Its botanical features include small, persistent bracts and a unique leaf morphology that aids in identification. It plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
